title.raw: 《蕭相國世家》 House of Chancellor Xiao

sentences.zh: 蕭相國何者，沛豐人也。

translations.literal: Prime Minister Xiao He was a man from Feng in Pei.
translations.idiomatic: Prime Minister Xiao He hailed from Feng in Pei.

sentences.zh: 以文無害為沛主吏掾。

translations.literal: Because he was literate and harmless, he became the chief clerk of Pei.
translations.idiomatic: Because he was literate and inoffensive, he became the chief clerk of Pei.

translations.literal: Chancellor Xiao He was a native of Pei and Feng counties. He served as an assistant to the Pei county magistrate because of his literacy and harmless character.

sentences.zh: 高祖為布衣時，何數以吏事護高祖。

translations.literal: When Gaozu was a commoner, He frequently used his official duties to protect Gaozu.
translations.idiomatic: When Gaozu was a commoner, He frequently used his official duties to protect Gaozu.

sentences.zh: 高祖為亭長，常左右之。

translations.literal: When Gaozu became pavilion chief, He constantly assisted him.
translations.idiomatic: When Gaozu became pavilion chief, He constantly supported him.

sentences.zh: 高祖以吏繇咸陽，吏皆送奉錢三，何獨以五。

translations.literal: When Gaozu was drafted as an official to Xianyang, all the officials presented three coins for the farewell feast, but He alone presented five.
translations.idiomatic: When Gaozu was drafted as an official to Xianyang, all the officials presented three coins for the farewell feast, but He alone presented five.

translations.literal: When Gaozu was still a commoner, He frequently used his official duties to protect Gaozu. When Gaozu became a village head, He was constantly at his side. When Gaozu was sent to Xianyang on official business, while other officials all sent three cash as tribute, He alone sent five.

sentences.zh: 秦御史監郡者與從事，常辨之。

translations.literal: The Qin imperial secretary who supervised the commandery and worked with him always praised him.
translations.idiomatic: The Qin imperial secretary who supervised the commandery and worked with him always commended him.

sentences.zh: 何乃給泗水卒史事，第一。

translations.literal: He then served as clerk for the Sishui district, ranking first.
translations.idiomatic: He then served as clerk for the Sishui district, ranking first.

sentences.zh: 秦御史欲入言徵何，何固請，得毋行。

translations.literal: The Qin imperial secretary wished to enter and recommend summoning He, but He firmly declined and managed not to go.
translations.idiomatic: The Qin imperial secretary wished to enter and recommend summoning He, but He firmly declined and managed not to go.

translations.literal: A Qin imperial secretary who was supervising the commandery and working with him always defended him. He then served as secretary to the Sishui warden, and was first in merit. The Qin imperial secretary wanted to go in and recommend recruiting He, but He firmly requested not to go.

sentences.zh: 及高祖起為沛公，何常為丞督事。

translations.literal: When Gaozu rose up to become Lord of Pei, He constantly served as deputy and oversaw affairs.
translations.idiomatic: When Gaozu rose up to become Lord of Pei, He constantly served as deputy and oversaw affairs.

sentences.zh: 沛公至咸陽，諸將皆爭走金帛財物之府分之，何獨先入收秦丞相御史律令圖書藏之。

translations.literal: When the Lord of Pei reached Xianyang, all the generals rushed to the treasuries of gold, silk, and valuables to divide them up, but He alone first entered and collected the Qin chancellor's and imperial secretary's statutes, orders, maps, and books to store them away.
translations.idiomatic: When the Lord of Pei reached Xianyang, all the generals rushed to the treasuries of gold, silk, and valuables to divide them up, but He alone first entered and gathered the Qin chancellor's and imperial secretary's statutes, orders, maps, and books to preserve them.

sentences.zh: 沛公為漢王，以何為丞相。

translations.literal: When the Lord of Pei became Han King, he made He chancellor.
translations.idiomatic: When the Lord of Pei became Han King, he made He chancellor.

sentences.zh: 項王與諸侯屠燒咸陽而去。

translations.literal: Xiang Yu and the feudal lords massacred and burned Xianyang and left.
translations.idiomatic: Xiang Yu and the feudal lords massacred and burned Xianyang and left.

sentences.zh: 漢王所以具知天下阸塞，戶口多少，彊弱之處，民所疾苦者，以何具得秦圖書也。

translations.literal: The reason the Han King fully knew the strategic passes of the realm, the number of households and population, the strong and weak places, and what the people suffered from was because He had obtained all the Qin maps and books.
translations.idiomatic: The reason the Han King fully knew the strategic passes of the realm, the number of households and population, the strong and weak places, and what the people suffered from was because He had obtained all the Qin maps and books.

sentences.zh: 何進言韓信，漢王以信為大將軍。

translations.literal: He recommended Han Xin, and the Han King made Xin grand general.
translations.idiomatic: He recommended Han Xin, and the Han King made Xin grand general.

sentences.zh: 語在淮陰侯事中。

translations.literal: The words are in the affairs of Marquis Huaiyin.
translations.idiomatic: The words are in the affairs of Marquis Huaiyin.

translations.literal: When Gaozu rose up to become Duke of Pei, He constantly served as assistant and oversaw affairs. When the Duke of Pei reached Xianyang, all the generals rushed to the treasuries storing gold, silks, and valuables to divide them up, but He alone first entered and collected the Qin chancellor's and imperial secretary's laws, ordinances, maps, and books to store them away. When the Duke of Pei became King of Han, he appointed He as chancellor. Xiang Yu and the feudal lords slaughtered and burned Xianyang and left. The King of Han was able to fully know the strategic passes of the realm, the number of households and population, strong and weak areas, and what the people suffered from, because He had obtained all the Qin maps and books. He recommended Han Xin, and the King of Han appointed Xin as supreme general. The account is in the affairs of the Marquis of Huaiyin.

sentences.zh: 漢王引兵東定三秦，何以丞相留收巴蜀，填撫諭告，使給軍食。

translations.literal: When the Han King led troops east to pacify the Three Qins, He as chancellor remained to collect Bashu, fill and pacify by proclamation and instruction, and supply the army with food.
translations.idiomatic: When the Han King led troops east to pacify the Three Qins, He as chancellor remained to gather Bashu, fill and pacify by proclamation and instruction, and supply the army with food.

sentences.zh: 漢二年，漢王與諸侯擊楚，何守關中，侍太子，治櫟陽。

translations.literal: In Han year 2, the Han King together with the feudal lords attacked Chu. He guarded Guanzhong, attended to the crown prince, and governed Queyang.
translations.idiomatic: In Han year 2, the Han King together with the feudal lords attacked Chu. He guarded Guanzhong, attended to the crown prince, and governed Queyang.

sentences.zh: 為法令約束，立宗廟社稷宮室縣邑，輒奏上，可，許以從事；

translations.literal: He established statutes and regulations, erected ancestral temples, altars of soil and grain, palaces, chambers, districts, and counties. Whenever he memorialized upward, if approved, he was permitted to proceed;
translations.idiomatic: He established statutes and regulations, erected ancestral temples, altars of soil and grain, palaces, chambers, districts, and counties. Whenever he memorialized upward, if approved, he was permitted to proceed;

sentences.zh: 即不及奏上，輒以便宜施行，上來以聞。

translations.literal: if there was no time to memorialize upward, he would proceed according to what was expedient, and report upward when the emperor came.
translations.idiomatic: if there was no time to memorialize upward, he would proceed according to what was expedient, and report upward when the emperor came.

sentences.zh: 關中事計戶口轉漕給軍，漢王數失軍遁去，何常興關中卒，輒補缺。

translations.literal: Guanzhong affairs were calculated by households and population, transporting grain to supply the army. The Han King frequently lost troops and fled, but He constantly raised Guanzhong soldiers and promptly filled the gaps.
translations.idiomatic: Guanzhong affairs were calculated by households and population, transporting grain to supply the army. The Han King frequently lost troops and fled, but He constantly raised Guanzhong soldiers and promptly filled the gaps.

sentences.zh: 上以此專屬任何關中事。

translations.literal: The emperor therefore specially entrusted all Guanzhong affairs to He.
translations.idiomatic: The emperor therefore specially entrusted all Guanzhong affairs to He.

translations.literal: The King of Han led troops east to pacify the Three Qins, while He as chancellor stayed behind to receive and organize Bashu, filling and comforting them with proclamations, enabling them to supply the army with food. In Han year 2, the King of Han attacked Chu together with the feudal lords, while He guarded Guanzhong, attended the crown prince, and governed Queyang. He established laws and regulations, erected ancestral temples, altars to the gods of soil and grain, palaces, and county seats, always memorializing upward—if approved, he was permitted to proceed; if there was no time to memorialize upward, he would act according to what was expedient, and report it when the emperor returned. For Guanzhong affairs, he calculated households and population, transported grain to supply the army. The King of Han frequently lost armies and fled, but He constantly raised Guanzhong troops to fill the gaps. Because of this, the emperor specially entrusted all Guanzhong matters to He alone.

sentences.zh: 漢三年，漢王與項羽相距京索之閒，上數使使勞苦丞相。

translations.literal: In Han year 3, the Han King confronted Xiang Yu between Jingsuo, and the emperor frequently sent envoys to console the chancellor.
translations.idiomatic: In Han year 3, the Han King confronted Xiang Yu between Jingsuo, and the emperor frequently sent envoys to console the chancellor.

sentences.zh: 鮑生謂丞相曰：「王暴衣露蓋，數使使勞苦君者，有疑君心也。

translations.literal: Bao Sheng told the chancellor: 'The king exposes himself to wind and dew, frequently sending envoys to console you—this shows doubt in his heart toward you.
translations.idiomatic: Bao Sheng told the chancellor: 'The king exposes himself to wind and dew, frequently sending envoys to console you—this shows doubt in his heart toward you.

sentences.zh: 為君計，莫若遣君子孫昆弟能勝兵者悉詣軍所，上必益信君。」

translations.literal: For your sake, nothing would be better than sending all your sons, grandsons, younger brothers who can bear arms to the army camp—the emperor will certainly trust you even more.'
translations.idiomatic: For your sake, nothing would be better than sending all your sons, grandsons, younger brothers who can bear arms to the army camp—the emperor will certainly trust you even more.'

sentences.zh: 於是何從其計，漢王大說。

translations.literal: Thus He followed this plan, and the Han King was greatly pleased.
translations.idiomatic: Thus He followed this plan, and the Han King was greatly pleased.

translations.literal: In Han year 3, the King of Han confronted Xiang Yu between Jing and Suo, and the emperor repeatedly sent envoys to console and thank Chancellor He. Bao Sheng told the chancellor: 'The king exposes himself to wind and rain, repeatedly sending envoys to console and thank you—there must be suspicion in his heart toward you. For your sake, it would be best to send your sons, grandsons, and brothers who can bear arms to all go to the army camp—the king will certainly trust you even more.' Thus He followed this plan, and the King of Han was greatly pleased.

sentences.zh: 漢五年，既殺項羽，定天下，論功行封。

translations.literal: In Han year 5, after killing Xiang Yu and pacifying the realm, they discussed merits and bestowed enfeoffments.
translations.idiomatic: In Han year 5, after killing Xiang Yu and pacifying the realm, they discussed merits and bestowed enfeoffments.

sentences.zh: 群臣爭功，歲餘功不決。

translations.literal: The ministers disputed over merits, and for more than a year the merits were not decided.
translations.idiomatic: The ministers disputed over merits, and for more than a year the merits were not decided.

sentences.zh: 高祖以蕭何功最盛，封為酂侯，所食邑多。

translations.literal: Gaozu considered Xiao He's merit the greatest, enfeoffing him as Marquis of Cuo, with many fief households.
translations.idiomatic: Gaozu considered Xiao He's merit the greatest, enfeoffing him as Marquis of Cuo, with many fief households.

sentences.zh: 功臣皆曰：「臣等身被堅執銳，多者百餘戰，少者數十合，攻城略地，大小镑有差。

translations.literal: All the meritorious ministers said: 'We have worn armor and wielded sharp weapons, the many fought over a hundred battles, the few fought several dozen engagements, attacking cities and seizing territory, with distinctions between large and small contributions.
translations.idiomatic: All the meritorious ministers said: 'We have worn armor and wielded sharp weapons, the many fought over a hundred battles, the few fought several dozen engagements, attacking cities and seizing territory, with distinctions between large and small contributions.

sentences.zh: 今蕭何未嘗有汗馬之勞，徒持文墨議論，不戰，顧反居臣等上，何也？」

translations.literal: Now Xiao He has never had the labor of sweating horses, merely holding brush and ink to discuss affairs, not fighting, yet instead he ranks above us all—why is this?'
translations.idiomatic: Now Xiao He has never had the labor of sweating horses, merely holding brush and ink to discuss affairs, not fighting, yet instead he ranks above us all—why is this?'

sentences.zh: 高帝曰：「諸君知獵乎？」

translations.literal: Gaozu said: 'Do you gentlemen know hunting?'
translations.idiomatic: Gaozu said, 'Do you gentlemen know hunting?'

sentences.zh: 曰：「知之。」

translations.literal: They said: 'We know it.'
translations.idiomatic: They said, 'We know it.'

sentences.zh: 「知獵狗乎？」

translations.literal: 'Do you know hunting dogs?'
translations.idiomatic: 'Do you know hunting dogs?'

sentences.zh: 曰：「知之。」

translations.literal: They said: 'We know them.'
translations.idiomatic: They said, 'We know them.'

sentences.zh: 高帝曰：「夫獵，追殺獸兔者狗也，而發蹤指示獸處者人也。

translations.literal: Gaozu said: 'In hunting, those who pursue and kill beasts and rabbits are dogs, while those who discern tracks and point out where the beasts are are humans.
translations.idiomatic: Gaozu said, 'In hunting, those who pursue and kill beasts and rabbits are dogs, while those who discern tracks and point out where the beasts are are humans.

sentences.zh: 今諸君徒能得走獸耳，功狗也。

translations.literal: Now you gentlemen can only catch fleeing beasts—your merit is that of dogs.
translations.idiomatic: Now you gentlemen can only catch fleeing beasts—your merit is that of hounds.

sentences.zh: 至如蕭何，發蹤指示，功人也。

translations.literal: As for Xiao He, he discerns tracks and points them out—his merit is that of a human.'
translations.idiomatic: As for Xiao He, he discerns tracks and points them out—his merit is that of a man.'

sentences.zh: 且諸君獨以身隨我，多者兩三人。

translations.literal: 'Moreover, you gentlemen followed me with only your own persons, at most two or three people.
translations.idiomatic: 'Moreover, you gentlemen followed me with only your own persons, at most two or three people.

sentences.zh: 今蕭何舉宗數十人皆隨我，功不可忘也。」

translations.literal: Now Xiao He raised his entire clan of several dozen people to all follow me—his merit cannot be forgotten.'
translations.idiomatic: Now Xiao He raised his entire clan of several dozen people to all follow me—his merit cannot be forgotten.'

sentences.zh: 群臣皆莫敢言。

translations.literal: All the ministers dared not speak further.
translations.idiomatic: All the ministers dared not speak further.

translations.literal: In Han year 5, after killing Xiang Yu and pacifying the realm, they discussed merits and carried out enfeoffments. The ministers disputed over merits, and for more than a year merits were not decided. Gaozu considered Xiao He's merit the greatest, enfeoffing him as Marquis of Wan, with a large fief. All the meritorious officials said: 'We have worn armor and wielded sharp weapons, the most fought over a hundred battles, the least several dozen engagements, attacking cities and seizing territory, with greater and lesser distinctions. Now Xiao He has never had the labor of sweating horses, just holding documents and making plans, without fighting, yet he is placed above us all—why is this?' The emperor said: 'Do you gentlemen know hunting?' They said: 'We know it.' 'Do you know hunting dogs?' They said: 'We know them.' The emperor said: 'In hunting, the ones who chase and kill beasts and rabbits are the dogs, while the ones who find the tracks and point out where the beasts are are the people. Now you gentlemen can only catch running beasts, your merit is that of dogs. As for Xiao He, he finds tracks and points them out, his merit is that of people. Moreover, you gentlemen alone follow me with your bodies, the most are two or three people. Now Xiao He has brought his entire clan of dozens of people to follow me—his merit cannot be forgotten.' All the ministers dared not speak.

sentences.zh: 列侯畢已受封，及奏位次，皆曰：「平陽侯曹參身被七十創，攻城略地，功最多，宜第一。」

translations.literal: The marquises had all received their enfeoffments, and when they memorialized about positions in order, all said: 'Marquis Pingyang Cao Can suffered seventy wounds on his body, attacking cities and seizing territory—his merit is the greatest, he should be first.'
translations.idiomatic: The marquises had all received their enfeoffments, and when they memorialized about positions in order, all said, 'Marquis Pingyang Cao Can suffered seventy wounds on his body, attacking cities and seizing territory—his merit is the greatest, he should be first.'

sentences.zh: 上已橈功臣，多封蕭何，至位次未有以復難之，然心欲何第一。

translations.literal: The emperor had already thwarted the meritorious ministers by greatly enfeoffing Xiao He, but regarding positions in order, there was nothing to challenge it again, yet in his heart he wished He to be first.
translations.idiomatic: The emperor had already thwarted the meritorious ministers by greatly enfeoffing Xiao He, but regarding positions in order, there was nothing to challenge it again, yet in his heart he wished He to be first.

sentences.zh: 關內侯鄂君進曰：「群臣議皆誤。

translations.literal: Marquis within the Pass E Jun advanced and said: 'The ministers' discussion is all mistaken.
translations.idiomatic: Marquis within the Pass E Jun advanced and said, 'The ministers' discussion is all mistaken.

sentences.zh: 夫曹參雖有野戰略地之功，此特一時之事。

translations.literal: Although Cao Can has merit in attacking cities and seizing territory in the field, this is merely the matter of a single time.
translations.idiomatic: Although Cao Can has merit in attacking cities and seizing territory in the field, this is merely the matter of a single time.

sentences.zh: 夫上與楚相距五歲，常失軍亡眾，逃身遁者數矣。

translations.literal: The emperor confronted Chu for five years, frequently losing troops and men, escaping and fleeing several times.
translations.idiomatic: The emperor confronted Chu for five years, frequently losing troops and men, escaping and fleeing several times.

sentences.zh: 然蕭何常從關中遣軍補其處，非上所詔令召，而數萬眾會上之乏絕者數矣。

translations.literal: Yet Xiao He constantly sent troops from Guanzhong to fill the gaps, not by the emperor's edict or summons, and tens of thousands gathered to supply the emperor's shortages several times.
translations.idiomatic: Yet Xiao He constantly sent troops from Guanzhong to fill the gaps, not by the emperor's edict or summons, and tens of thousands gathered to supply the emperor's shortages several times.

sentences.zh: 夫漢與楚相守滎陽數年，軍無見糧，蕭何轉漕關中，給食不乏。

translations.literal: Han and Chu confronted each other at Xingyang for several years, the army had no visible grain, but Xiao He transported grain from Guanzhong, supplying food without shortage.
translations.idiomatic: Han and Chu confronted each other at Xingyang for several years, the army had no visible grain, but Xiao He transported grain from Guanzhong, supplying food without shortage.

sentences.zh: 陛下雖數亡山東，蕭何常全關中以待陛下，此萬世之功也。

translations.literal: Though Your Majesty frequently lost Shandong, Xiao He constantly preserved Guanzhong to await Your Majesty—this is merit for ten thousand generations.
translations.idiomatic: Though Your Majesty frequently lost Shandong, Xiao He constantly preserved Guanzhong to await Your Majesty—this is merit for ten thousand generations.

sentences.zh: 今雖亡曹參等百數，何缺於漢？

translations.literal: Now even if we lacked a hundred Cao Cans and the like, what would Han lack?
translations.idiomatic: Now even if we lacked a hundred Cao Cans and the like, what would Han lack?

sentences.zh: 漢得之不必待以全。

translations.literal: Han obtaining it does not necessarily depend on them for completeness.
translations.idiomatic: Han obtaining it does not necessarily depend on them for completeness.

sentences.zh: 柰何欲以一旦之功而加萬世之功哉！

translations.literal: How can one wish to place the merit of a single day above the merit of ten thousand generations!
translations.idiomatic: How can one wish to place the merit of a single day above the merit of ten thousand generations!

sentences.zh: 蕭何第一，曹參次之。」

translations.literal: Xiao He first, Cao Can second.'
translations.idiomatic: Xiao He ranks first, Cao Can second.'

sentences.zh: 高祖曰：「善。」

translations.literal: Gaozu said: 'Good.'
translations.idiomatic: Gaozu said, 'Good.'

sentences.zh: 於是乃令蕭何［第一］，賜帶劍履上殿，入朝不趨。

translations.literal: Thus he commanded Xiao He to be first, granting him the right to wear sword and shoes on the hall, and not to hasten when entering court.
translations.idiomatic: Thus he commanded Xiao He to be first, granting him the right to wear sword and shoes on the hall, and not to hasten when entering court.

translations.literal: After all the marquises had received their enfeoffments, when memorializing about rank order, they all said: 'Marquis Pingyang Cao Can has suffered seventy wounds on his body, attacked cities and seized territory, his merit is the greatest, he should be first.' The emperor had already bent the meritorious officials and given Xiao He much in enfeoffment, but regarding rank order he had no way to rebut the difficulty, yet in his heart he wanted He to be first. Marquis within the Passes E Jun advanced and said: 'All the ministers' discussions are mistaken. Although Cao Can has the merit of campaigning and seizing territory in the wilds, this is just a temporary matter. The emperor has confronted Chu for five years, frequently losing armies and troops, escaping and fleeing several times. Yet Xiao He constantly sent armies from Guanzhong to fill the gaps, not summoned by the emperor's edicts, and tens of thousands gathered to supply what the emperor lacked several times. Han and Chu confronted each other at Xingyang for several years, the army had no visible grain, but Xiao He transported grain from Guanzhong, never lacking in provisions. Although the emperor several times lost Shandong, Xiao He always kept Guanzhong intact to wait for the emperor—this is merit for ten thousand generations. Now even if we lacked a hundred Cao Cans, what harm would it do to Han? Han obtaining them is not necessary for completeness.' How can one want to add merit for ten thousand generations with merit from a single day! Xiao He first, Cao Can second.' Gaozu said: 'Good.' Thus he ordered Xiao He [first], granting him the right to wear sword and shoes while ascending the hall, and not to hasten when entering court.

sentences.zh: 上曰：「吾聞進賢受上賞。

translations.literal: The emperor said: 'I have heard that advancing the worthy receives the highest reward.
translations.idiomatic: The emperor said, 'I have heard that advancing the worthy receives the highest reward.

sentences.zh: 蕭何功雖高，得鄂君乃益明。」

translations.literal: Though Xiao He's merit is high, obtaining E Jun makes it even clearer.'
translations.idiomatic: Though Xiao He's merit is high, obtaining E Jun makes it even more apparent.'

sentences.zh: 於是因鄂君故所食關內侯邑封為安平侯。

translations.literal: Thus because of E Jun, he enfeoffed the fief households that E Jun had as Marquis within the Pass as Marquis of Anping.
translations.idiomatic: Thus because of E Jun, he enfeoffed the fief households that E Jun had as Marquis within the Pass as Marquis of Anping.

sentences.zh: 是日，悉封何父子兄弟十餘人，皆有食邑。

translations.literal: That day, he completely enfeoffed He's father, sons, and brothers more than ten people, all with fief households.
translations.idiomatic: That day, he completely enfeoffed more than ten of He's father, sons, and brothers, all with fief households.

sentences.zh: 乃益封何二千戶，以帝嘗繇咸陽時何送我獨贏錢二也。

translations.literal: He increased He's enfeoffment by two thousand households, because when the emperor was once drafted to Xianyang, He sent him extra coins alone.
translations.idiomatic: He increased He's enfeoffment by two thousand households, because when the emperor was once drafted to Xianyang, He sent him extra coins alone.

translations.literal: The emperor said: 'I have heard that recommending the worthy receives the highest reward. Although Xiao He's merit is high, obtaining E Jun makes it even clearer.' Thus he enfeoffed E Jun with the marquisate within the passes he had been eating as a marquis, making him Marquis of Anping. On that day, he fully enfeoffed He's father, sons, and brothers more than ten people, all with fiefs. He further increased He's fief by 2000 households, because when the emperor was once sent to Xianyang on official business, He sent me money that was uniquely extra.

sentences.zh: 漢十一年，陳豨反，高祖自將，至邯鄲。

translations.literal: In Han year 11, Chen Xi rebelled. Gaozu personally led troops and arrived at Handan.
translations.idiomatic: In Han year 11, Chen Xi rebelled. Gaozu personally led troops and arrived at Handan.

sentences.zh: 未罷，淮陰侯謀反關中，呂后用蕭何計，誅淮陰侯，語在淮陰事中。

translations.literal: Before departing, Marquis Huaiyin plotted rebellion in Guanzhong. Empress Lü used Xiao He's plan to execute Marquis Huaiyin. The words are in the affairs of Huaiyin.
translations.idiomatic: Before departing, Marquis Huaiyin plotted rebellion in Guanzhong. Empress Lü used Xiao He's plan to execute Marquis Huaiyin. The words are in the affairs of Huaiyin.

sentences.zh: 上已聞淮陰侯誅，使使拜丞相何為相國，益封五千戶，令卒五百人一都尉為相國衛。

translations.literal: The emperor had already heard of Marquis Huaiyin's execution and sent an envoy to appoint Chancellor He as Prime Minister, increasing his enfeoffment by five thousand households, and commanding five hundred soldiers and one Commandant to guard the Prime Minister.
translations.idiomatic: The emperor had already heard of Marquis Huaiyin's execution and sent an envoy to appoint Chancellor He as Prime Minister, increasing his enfeoffment by five thousand households, and commanding five hundred soldiers and one Commandant to guard the Prime Minister.

sentences.zh: 諸君皆賀，召平獨弔。

translations.literal: All the ministers congratulated him, but Zhao Ping alone offered condolences.
translations.idiomatic: All the ministers congratulated him, but Zhao Ping alone offered condolences.

sentences.zh: 召平者，故秦東陵侯。

translations.literal: Zhao Ping was formerly the Qin Marquis of Dongling.
translations.idiomatic: Zhao Ping was formerly the Qin Marquis of Dongling.

sentences.zh: 秦破，為布衣，貧，種瓜於長安城東，瓜美，故世俗謂之「東陵瓜」，從召平以為名也。

translations.literal: After Qin was destroyed, he became a commoner, poor, and grew melons east of Chang'an city. The melons were delicious, so the world called them 'Dongling melons,' taking the name from Zhao Ping.
translations.idiomatic: After Qin was destroyed, he became a commoner, poor, and grew melons east of Chang'an city. The melons were delicious, so the world called them 'Dongling melons,' taking the name from Zhao Ping.

sentences.zh: 召平謂相國曰：「禍自此始矣。

translations.literal: Zhao Ping told the Prime Minister: 'Disaster begins from this.
translations.idiomatic: Zhao Ping told the Prime Minister, 'Disaster begins from this.

sentences.zh: 上暴露於外而君守於中，非被矢石之事而益君封置衛者，以今者淮陰侯新反於中，疑君心矣。

translations.literal: The emperor is exposed abroad while you guard within. Though not suffering arrow and stone affairs, yet increasing your enfeoffment and placing guards for you—because recently Marquis Huaiyin rebelled within, he doubts your heart.'
translations.idiomatic: The emperor is exposed abroad while you guard within. Though not suffering arrow and stone affairs, yet increasing your enfeoffment and placing guards for you—because recently Marquis Huaiyin rebelled within, he doubts your heart.'

sentences.zh: 夫置衛衛君，非以寵君也。

translations.literal: Placing guards to guard you is not to favor you.
translations.idiomatic: Placing guards to guard you is not to honor you.

sentences.zh: 願君讓封勿受，悉以家私財佐軍，則上心說。」

translations.literal: I wish you to decline the enfeoffment and not accept it, using all your private family wealth to assist the army, then the emperor's heart will be pleased.'
translations.idiomatic: I wish you to decline the enfeoffment and not accept it, using all your private family wealth to assist the army, then the emperor's heart will be pleased.'

sentences.zh: 相國從其計，高帝乃大喜。

translations.literal: The Prime Minister followed his plan, and Gaozu was greatly pleased.
translations.idiomatic: The Prime Minister followed his plan, and Gaozu was greatly delighted.

translations.literal: In Han year 11, Chen Xi rebelled, Gaozu personally led troops and arrived at Handan. Before returning, the Marquis of Huaiyin plotted rebellion in Guanzhong, Empress Lü used Xiao He's plan to execute the Marquis of Huaiyin—the account is in the Huaiyin affairs. The emperor had heard of the Marquis of Huaiyin's execution and sent an envoy to appoint Chancellor He as prime minister, increasing his fief by 5000 households, commanding 500 troops with a commandery lieutenant as prime minister's guard. All the gentlemen congratulated him, but Zhao Ping alone mourned. Zhao Ping was formerly the Qin Marquis of Dongling. After Qin was destroyed, he became a commoner, poor, grew melons east of Chang'an city, the melons were delicious, so common people call them 'Dongling melons', taking Zhao Ping as their name. Zhao Ping told the prime minister: 'Disaster begins from this. The emperor is exposed outdoors while you guard within, not involved in arrow and stone matters yet increasing your fief and setting up guards—because recently the Marquis of Huaiyin rebelled within, there is suspicion toward your heart. Setting up guards to guard you is not to favor you. I wish you would decline the fief and not accept it, use all your private wealth to aid the army, then the emperor's heart will be pleased.' The prime minister followed his plan, and Gaozu was greatly pleased.

sentences.zh: 漢十二年秋，黥布反，上自將擊之，數使使問相國何為。

translations.literal: In Han year 12 autumn, Ying Bu rebelled. The emperor personally led troops to attack him, frequently sending envoys to ask what the Prime Minister was doing.
translations.idiomatic: In Han year 12 autumn, Ying Bu rebelled. The emperor personally led troops to attack him, frequently sending envoys to ask what the Prime Minister was doing.

sentences.zh: 相國為上在軍，乃拊循勉力百姓，悉以所有佐軍，如陳豨時。

translations.literal: The Prime Minister, because the emperor was in the army, stroked and encouraged the people, using all he had to assist the army, like during Chen Xi's time.
translations.idiomatic: The Prime Minister, because the emperor was in the army, stroked and encouraged the people, using all he had to assist the army, like during Chen Xi's time.

sentences.zh: 客有說相國曰：「君滅族不久矣。

translations.literal: A guest advised the Prime Minister: 'Your clan will be extinguished soon.
translations.idiomatic: A guest advised the Prime Minister, 'Your clan will be extinguished soon.

sentences.zh: 夫君位為相國，功第一，可復加哉？

translations.literal: Your position is Prime Minister, merit first—can it be increased further?
translations.idiomatic: Your position is Prime Minister, merit first—can it be increased further?

sentences.zh: 然君初入關中，得百姓心，十餘年矣，皆附君，常復孳孳得民和。

translations.literal: Yet when you first entered Guanzhong, you won the people's hearts. For more than ten years, all have attached themselves to you, and you constantly diligently obtain the people's harmony.
translations.idiomatic: Yet when you first entered Guanzhong, you won the people's hearts. For more than ten years, all have attached themselves to you, and you constantly diligently obtain the people's harmony.

sentences.zh: 上所為數問君者，畏君傾動關中。

translations.literal: The reason the emperor frequently asks about you is that he fears you will overturn Guanzhong.
translations.idiomatic: The reason the emperor frequently asks about you is that he fears you will overturn Guanzhong.

sentences.zh: 今君胡不多買田地，賤貰貸以自汙？

translations.literal: Now why don't you buy more fields and land, borrow cheaply to defile yourself?
translations.idiomatic: Now why don't you buy more fields and land, borrow cheaply to defile yourself?

sentences.zh: 上心乃安。」

translations.literal: Then the emperor's heart will be at peace.'
translations.idiomatic: Then the emperor's heart will be at peace.'

sentences.zh: 於是相國從其計，上乃大說。

translations.literal: Thus the Prime Minister followed his plan, and the emperor was greatly pleased.
translations.idiomatic: Thus the Prime Minister followed his plan, and the emperor was greatly pleased.

translations.literal: In autumn of Han year 12, Ying Bu rebelled, the emperor personally led troops to attack him, repeatedly sending envoys to ask what the prime minister was doing. The prime minister, because the emperor was in the army, stroked and encouraged the people, using all he had to aid the army, like during Chen Xi's time. A guest advised the prime minister: 'Your clan will be extinguished soon. Your position is prime minister, merit first—can it be added to further? Yet when you first entered Guanzhong, you gained the people's hearts, more than ten years ago, all are attached to you, and you constantly diligently obtain the people's harmony. The reason the emperor repeatedly asks about you is fear that you will shake Guanzhong. Now why don't you buy more fields and lend money cheaply to defile yourself? Then the emperor's heart will be at peace.' Thus the prime minister followed his plan, and the emperor was greatly pleased.

sentences.zh: 上罷布軍歸，民道遮行上書，言相國賤彊買民田宅數千萬。

translations.literal: The emperor disbanded the Bu army and returned. People along the road intercepted him to submit memorials, saying the Prime Minister forcibly bought people's fields and houses cheaply for tens of millions.
translations.idiomatic: The emperor disbanded the Bu army and returned. People along the road intercepted him to submit memorials, saying the Prime Minister forcibly bought people's fields and houses cheaply for tens of millions.

sentences.zh: 上至，相國謁。

translations.literal: When the emperor arrived, the Prime Minister made his audience.
translations.idiomatic: When the emperor arrived, the Prime Minister made his audience.

sentences.zh: 上笑曰：「夫相國乃利民！」

translations.literal: The emperor laughed: 'The Prime Minister is benefiting the people!'
translations.idiomatic: The emperor laughed, 'The Prime Minister is benefiting the people!'

sentences.zh: 民所上書皆以與相國，曰：「君自謝民。」

translations.literal: He gave all the people's submitted memorials to the Prime Minister, saying: 'You personally apologize to the people.'
translations.idiomatic: He gave all the people's submitted memorials to the Prime Minister, saying, 'You personally apologize to the people.'

sentences.zh: 相國因為民請曰：「長安地狹，上林中多空地，棄，願令民得入田，毋收槁為禽獸食。」

translations.literal: The Prime Minister thus petitioned for the people: 'Chang'an land is narrow. In Shanglin Park there is much empty land, abandoned. I wish to allow people to enter and farm it, not collecting the stubble for birds and beasts to eat.'
translations.idiomatic: The Prime Minister thus petitioned for the people, 'Chang'an land is narrow. In Shanglin Park there is much empty land, abandoned. I wish to allow people to enter and farm it, not collecting the stubble for birds and beasts to eat.'

sentences.zh: 上大怒曰：「相國多受賈人財物，乃為請吾苑！」

translations.literal: The emperor was greatly angered: 'The Prime Minister has received much wealth from merchants, and thus petitions for my park!'
translations.idiomatic: The emperor was greatly angered, 'The Prime Minister has received much wealth from merchants, and thus petitions for my park!'

sentences.zh: 乃下相國廷尉，械系之。

translations.literal: He sent the Prime Minister to the Chamberlain for Law Enforcement, shackling and binding him.
translations.idiomatic: He sent the Prime Minister to the Chamberlain for Law Enforcement, shackling and imprisoning him.

sentences.zh: 數日，王衛尉侍，前問曰：「相國何大罪，陛下系之暴也？」

translations.literal: Several days later, Wang Weiwei attended and asked before him: 'What great crime has the Prime Minister committed that Your Majesty shackles him so violently?'
translations.idiomatic: Several days later, Wang Weiwei attended and asked before him, 'What great crime has the Prime Minister committed that Your Majesty shackles him so violently?'

sentences.zh: 上曰：「吾聞李斯相秦皇帝，有善歸主，有惡自與。

translations.literal: The emperor said: 'I have heard that Li Si served as Qin emperor's chancellor, attributing good to the ruler, taking evil upon himself.
translations.idiomatic: The emperor said, 'I have heard that Li Si served as Qin emperor's chancellor, attributing good to the ruler, taking evil upon himself.

sentences.zh: 今相國多受賈豎金而為民請吾苑，以自媚於民，故系治之。」

translations.literal: Now the Prime Minister has received much gold from merchants and petitions for my park on behalf of the people, to curry favor with the people, thus I shackle and investigate him.'
translations.idiomatic: Now the Prime Minister has received much gold from merchants and petitions for my park on behalf of the people, to ingratiate himself with the people, thus I shackle and investigate him.'

sentences.zh: 王衛尉曰：「夫職事茍有便於民而請之，真宰相事，陛下柰何乃疑相國受賈人錢乎！

translations.literal: Wang Weiwei said: 'If in one's duties one petitions for what benefits the people, that is truly a prime minister's affair. How can Your Majesty doubt that the Prime Minister received merchants' money!'
translations.idiomatic: Wang Weiwei said, 'If in one's duties one petitions for what benefits the people, that is truly a prime minister's affair. How can Your Majesty doubt that the Prime Minister received merchants' money!

sentences.zh: 且陛下距楚數歲，陳豨、黥布反，陛下自將而往，當是時，相國守關中，搖足則關以西非陛下有也。

translations.literal: Moreover, Your Majesty confronted Chu for several years. Chen Xi and Ying Bu rebelled. Your Majesty personally led troops there. At that time, the Prime Minister guarded Guanzhong—if he stamped his foot, west of the pass would not be yours.
translations.idiomatic: Moreover, Your Majesty confronted Chu for several years. Chen Xi and Ying Bu rebelled. Your Majesty personally led troops there. At that time, the Prime Minister guarded Guanzhong—if he stamped his foot, west of the pass would not be yours.

sentences.zh: 相國不以此時為利，今乃利賈人之金乎？

translations.literal: The Prime Minister did not take advantage at that time—now would he take advantage of merchants' gold?
translations.idiomatic: The Prime Minister did not take advantage at that time—now would he take advantage of merchants' gold?

sentences.zh: 且秦以不聞其過亡天下，李斯之分過，又何足法哉。

translations.literal: Moreover, Qin perished because they did not hear their faults. Li Si's sharing of faults—what is there to emulate?
translations.idiomatic: Moreover, Qin perished because they did not hear their faults. Li Si's sharing of faults—what is there to emulate?

sentences.zh: 陛下何疑宰相之淺也。」

translations.literal: How shallow is Your Majesty's doubt of the prime minister.'
translations.idiomatic: How shallow is Your Majesty's doubt of the prime minister.'

sentences.zh: 高帝不懌。

translations.literal: Gaozu was displeased.
translations.idiomatic: Gaozu was displeased.

sentences.zh: 是日，使使持節赦出相國。

translations.literal: That day, he sent an envoy holding the tally to pardon and release the Prime Minister.
translations.idiomatic: That day, he sent an envoy holding the tally to pardon and release the Prime Minister.

sentences.zh: 相國年老，素恭謹，入，徒跣謝。

translations.literal: The Prime Minister was old and usually respectful. He entered barefoot to apologize.
translations.idiomatic: The Prime Minister was old and usually respectful. He entered barefoot to apologize.

sentences.zh: 高帝曰：「相國休矣！

translations.literal: Gaozu said: 'Prime Minister, that's enough!
translations.idiomatic: Gaozu said, 'Prime Minister, that's enough!

sentences.zh: 相國為民請苑，吾不許，我不過為桀紂主，而相國為賢相。

translations.literal: The Prime Minister petitions for the park on behalf of the people. I do not permit it. I am merely a Jie or Zhou ruler, while the Prime Minister is a worthy chancellor.
translations.idiomatic: The Prime Minister petitions for the park on behalf of the people. I do not permit it. I am merely a Jie or Zhou ruler, while the Prime Minister is a worthy chancellor.

sentences.zh: 吾故系相國，欲令百姓聞吾過也。」

translations.literal: I therefore shackled the Prime Minister to make the people hear of my faults.'
translations.idiomatic: I therefore shackled the Prime Minister to make the people hear of my faults.'

translations.literal: The emperor dismissed the Bu army and returned, people along the road intercepted him and presented memorials, saying the prime minister bought people's fields and houses cheaply and forcibly for several thousand. The emperor arrived, and the prime minister came to greet him. The emperor laughed and said: 'The prime minister is benefiting the people!' He gave all the people's memorials to the prime minister, saying: 'You personally thank the people.' The prime minister then requested for the people: 'Chang'an land is narrow, there is much empty land in Shanglin Park, abandoned—wish to allow people to enter and farm it, not collect the stubble for birds and beasts to eat.' The emperor greatly angered, said: 'The prime minister has received much wealth from merchants and is requesting my park for them!' He sent the prime minister to the superintendent of trials, shackled and imprisoned him. Several days later, the imperial guard commander attended and asked in front: 'What great crime has the prime minister committed that your majesty imprisons him so violently?' The emperor said: 'I heard that Li Si served as chancellor to the Qin emperor, attributed good to the ruler, took evil upon himself. Now the prime minister has received much gold from merchant lackeys and is requesting my park for the people to ingratiate himself with the people, thus I imprison and investigate him.' The imperial guard commander said: 'If in official duties one finds what benefits the people and requests it, this is truly a prime minister's business—why does your majesty suspect the prime minister received merchants' money!' Moreover, your majesty confronted Chu for several years, Chen Xi and Ying Bu rebelled, your majesty personally led troops and went, at that time the prime minister guarded Guanzhong—if he shook his foot then west of the passes would not be yours. The prime minister did not take advantage at that time, now would he take advantage of merchants' gold? Moreover Qin perished because it did not hear its faults, Li Si's dividing faults—what is worthy of imitating? Why does your majesty have such shallow suspicion of the prime minister.' Gaozu was displeased. That day he sent an envoy holding the tally to pardon and release the prime minister. The prime minister was old, habitually respectful and cautious, entered barefoot to apologize. Gaozu said: 'Prime minister, enough! The prime minister requested the park for the people, I did not permit it—I am no more than a Jie or Zhou ruler, while the prime minister is a worthy prime minister. I deliberately imprisoned the prime minister to let the people hear of my faults.'

sentences.zh: 何素不與曹參相能，及何病，孝惠自臨視相國病，因問曰：「君即百歲後，誰可代君者？」

translations.literal: He normally did not get along with Cao Can. When He fell ill, Emperor Hui personally visited to see the Prime Minister's illness, and asked: 'If you pass away after a hundred years, who can replace you?'
translations.idiomatic: He normally did not get along with Cao Can. When He fell ill, Emperor Hui personally visited to see the Prime Minister's illness, and asked, 'If you pass away after a hundred years, who can replace you?'

sentences.zh: 對曰：「知臣莫如主。」

translations.literal: He replied: 'No one knows a minister better than his ruler.'
translations.idiomatic: He replied, 'No one knows a minister better than his ruler.'

sentences.zh: 孝惠曰：「曹參何如？」

translations.literal: Emperor Hui said: 'What about Cao Can?'
translations.idiomatic: Emperor Hui said, 'What about Cao Can?'

sentences.zh: 何頓首曰：「帝得之矣！

translations.literal: He bowed his head and said: 'Your Majesty has found the right one!
translations.idiomatic: He bowed his head and said, 'Your Majesty has found the right one!

sentences.zh: 臣死不恨矣！」

translations.literal: I will die without regret!'
translations.idiomatic: I will die without regret!'

translations.literal: He was normally not on good terms with Cao Can, and when He became ill, Emperor Hui personally visited to see the prime minister's illness, and asked: 'If after you reach a hundred years, who can replace you?' He replied: 'No one knows a minister better than his ruler.' Emperor Hui said: 'What about Cao Can?' He bowed his head to the ground and said: 'Your majesty has obtained him! I will die without regret!'

sentences.zh: 何置田宅必居窮處，為家不治垣屋。

translations.literal: When He acquired fields and houses, he always lived in poor places. For his household, he did not repair walls or roofs.
translations.idiomatic: When He acquired fields and houses, he always lived in poor places. For his household, he did not repair walls or roofs.

sentences.zh: 曰：「後世賢，師吾儉；

translations.literal: He said: 'If later generations are worthy, they will emulate my frugality;
translations.idiomatic: He said, 'If later generations are worthy, they will emulate my frugality;

sentences.zh: 不賢，毋為勢家所奪。」

translations.literal: if not worthy, do not let powerful families seize it.'
translations.idiomatic: if not worthy, do not let powerful families seize it.'

translations.literal: He placed his fields and houses in poor locations, and for his household did not repair walls and roofs. He said: 'If later generations are worthy, they will emulate my frugality; if not worthy, do not let powerful families seize it.'

sentences.zh: 孝惠二年，相國何卒，謚為文終侯。

translations.literal: In Emperor Hui's second year, Prime Minister He died and was given the posthumous title Marquis Wenzhong.
translations.idiomatic: In Emperor Hui's second year, Prime Minister He passed away and was given the posthumous title Marquis Wenzhong.

translations.literal: In Emperor Hui year 2, Prime Minister He died, given the posthumous title Marquis of Wen.

sentences.zh: 後嗣以罪失侯者四世，絕，天子輒復求何後，封續酂侯，功臣莫得比焉。

translations.literal: His descendants lost the marquisate due to crimes for four generations, and the line was extinguished. The Son of Heaven always sought He's descendants again, enfeoffing them to continue the Cuo marquisate. No other meritorious minister could compare.
translations.idiomatic: His descendants lost the marquisate due to crimes for four generations, and the line was extinguished. The Son of Heaven always sought He's descendants again, enfeoffing them to continue the Cuo marquisate. No other meritorious minister could compare.

translations.literal: Later descendants lost the marquisate through crime for four generations, it was extinguished, but the Son of Heaven always sought He's descendants again, enfeoffed them to continue the Wan marquisate—no other meritorious official could compare.

sentences.zh: 太史公曰：蕭相國何於秦時為刀筆吏，錄錄未有奇節。

translations.literal: The Grand Historian says: Prime Minister Xiao He during Qin times was a clerk, mediocre without exceptional conduct.
translations.idiomatic: The Grand Historian says: Prime Minister Xiao He during Qin times was a clerk, mediocre without exceptional conduct.

sentences.zh: 及漢興，依日月之末光，何謹守管籥，因民之疾（奉）［秦］法，順流與之更始。

translations.literal: When Han arose, relying on the remaining light of sun and moon, He carefully guarded the key and flute, taking advantage of the people's hatred of Qin laws, flowing with them to make a new beginning.
translations.idiomatic: When Han arose, relying on the remaining light of sun and moon, He carefully guarded the key and flute, taking advantage of the people's hatred of Qin laws, flowing with them to make a new beginning.

sentences.zh: 淮陰、黥布等皆以誅滅，而何之勳爛焉。

translations.literal: Huaiyin, Ying Bu and others were all executed and perished, while He's merit shines brilliantly.
translations.idiomatic: Huaiyin, Ying Bu and others were all executed and perished, while He's merit shines brilliantly.

sentences.zh: 位冠群臣，聲施後世，與閎夭、散宜生等爭烈矣。

translations.literal: His position crowned all ministers, his reputation extends to later generations, contending with Hong Yao, San Yisheng and others in glory.
translations.idiomatic: His position topped all ministers, his reputation extends to later generations, contending with Hong Yao, San Yisheng and others in glory.

translations.literal: The Grand Historian says: Chancellor Xiao He during Qin times was a clerk with writing brush, undistinguished without extraordinary conduct. When Han arose, relying on the remaining light of sun and moon, He carefully guarded the keys and pipes, took advantage of the people's hatred of [Qin] law, followed the current and began anew with them. Huaiyin, Ying Bu and others all perished through execution, while He's merit shines brilliantly. His position crowned the ministers, his reputation extends to later generations, contending in glory with Hong Yao, San Yisheng and others.
